Client Selection for Federated Bayesian Learning

Jiarong Yang, Yuan Liu, and Rahif Kassab This work was supported in part by the Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61971196, Grant U1701265, and Grant U2001210. (Corresponding author: Yuan Liu.) J. Yang and Y. Liu are with school of Electronic and Information Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510641, China (e-mails: eejiarong@mail.scut.edu.cn, eeyliu@scut.edu.cn). Rahif Kassab is with the Kingâ€™s Communications, Learning and Information Processing (KCLIP) Lab Kingâ€™s College London, London WC2B4BG, U.K. (email: rahif.kassab@kcl.ac.uk).
Abstract

Distributed Stein Variational Gradient Descent (DSVGD) is a non-parametric distributed learning framework for federated Bayesian learning, where multiple clients jointly train a machine learning model by communicating a number of non-random and interacting particles with the server. Since communication resources are limited, selecting the clients with most informative local learning updates can improve the model convergence and communication efficiency. In this paper, we propose two selection schemes for DSVGD based on Kernelized Stein Discrepancy (KSD) and Hilbert Inner Product (HIP). We derive the upper bound on the decrease of the global free energy per iteration for both schemes, which is then minimized to speed up the model convergence. We evaluate and compare our schemes with conventional schemes in terms of model accuracy, convergence speed, and stability using various learning tasks and datasets.

Index Terms:
Federated Bayesian learning, scheduling, client selection, variational inference.

I Introduction

The rapid development of machine learning has impacted various aspects of todayâ€™s society, from autonomous vehicles to computer vision, bioscience and natural language processing [1]. Conventionally, training machine learning models relies on the availability of big datasets at a centralized remote location, e.g., a central server, where training is carried out. However, most data is generated in a distributed fashion, e.g., by edge devices/clients, and thus needs to be collected at the central server to enable training. With the increasing awareness for data security and privacy, uploading local data to a remote location is no longer a viable solution. To cope with this challenge, federated learning [2, 3, 4] was proposed as a distributed learning framework that performs model training at the client side using the clientâ€™s local dataset and then shares the clientâ€™s model with the server, where various models are aggregated. Thus, under this framework, the clientâ€™s data is preserved on their device. In some practical scenarios, such as medical diagnosis and autonomous driving, models need to provide not only predictions but also a calibrated confidence measure that reflects the amount by which the client can trust a given prediction. However, most federated learning algorithms are based on frequentist learning principle which is known to be unable to quantify epistemic uncertainty, yielding overconfident decisions [5, 6]. In contrast, Bayesian learning is more suitable in such scenarios as it provides a more accurate estimate of uncertainty by optimizing over the space of distributions of model parameters instead of a single vector of model parameters [7, 8].

The main goal of federated Bayesian learning is to train a global posterior by clients which exchange model parameters with a central server over a wireless channel [9, 10, 11]. Therefore, the convergence of the model is often affected by the number of communication rounds [12, 13] and data-heterogeneity [14, 15]. Specifically, on one hand, model training requires frequent exchanges of model parameters between the server and clients over a channel, so a large number of communication resources (i.e., time and frequency resources) will cause large communication delays, which in turn affects the convergence speed of the model. On the other hand, clients are isolated from each other, consequently, there is no guarantee that the data between clients is independent and identically distributed (IID). Such heterogeneity of clientâ€™s data will reduce the model accuracy and slow down the convergence speed. Therefore, it is concluded that local learning updates of distributed clients do not contribute equally to global model convergence [16, 17, 18]. A promising technique to tackle this issue is scheduling or client selection, i.e., select the clients with most informative data for participation so as to not only accelerate the learning process but also reduce communication overhead.

I-A Prior Work

Existing federated Bayesian learning techniques can be classified to two families: Monte Carlo (MC) sampling or Variational Inference (VI). MC-based federated Bayesian learning[19, 20] such as Distributed Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (DSGLD), maintains a number of Markov chains that are updated via local Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) and injects noise into the parameter updates [21, 19]. Unfortunately, the model convergence for such techniques is difficult to assess and the convergence speed is low. VI-based federated Bayesian learning [22, 11, 10, 23] such as Partitioned Variational Inference (PVI) optimizes over parametric posteriors from tractable families (e.g., the exponential family) using natural gradient descent [10]. However, limiting the optimization to tractable families incurs bias. Accordingly, Distributed Stein Variational Gradient Descent (DSVGD) has been proposed as a method to eliminate such bias by encoding the variational posterior with deterministic particles that are updated by each scheduled client using Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) [24]. When the number of particles is large enough, any posterior could be approximated. By tuning the number of particles, DSVGD can trade off bias, convergence speed and per-iteration complexity [23]. More details on SVGD and DSVGD are given in Section II.

One of the biggest challenges in federated learning is decreasing the communication load. This challenge, known as communication-efficient federated learning, recently received lots of interest in the wireless research community. More specifically, multiple techniques have been studied to decrease the communication load, for e.g., through the joint design of learning and communication such as learning update compression [25, 26], radio resource management [27, 28, 29] and over-the-air computation [30, 31, 32]. Another technique, often referred to as client selection or scheduling, exploits the difference in the clientsâ€™ model updates and selects the clients with the most informative updates in order to increase the convergence speed while decreasing the total communication load [16, 33, 34, 35]. For example, authors of [34] use gradient divergence to quantify the importance of each local update, and propose a novel importance and channel-aware scheduling policy. In [35], the inner product between each local gradient and the ground-truth global gradient is used to quantify the importance of data, and a fast convergent algorithm is proposed where the local update is weighted by the the inner product.

Most of the existing schemes considered in the literature are applicable to frequentist federated learning. In this paper, we explore the benefits of client selection for federated Bayesian learning. More specifically, we consider DSVGD [23], which is a non-parametric distributed variational inference framework for federated Bayesian learning. DSVGD uses a number of non-random and interacting particles to represent the variational posterior distribution of the modelâ€™s parameters. The particles are updated iteratively by each scheduled client using SVGD [24]. We propose and analyze two client selection approaches for DSVGD that lead to faster convergence and lower communication cost.

I-B Contributions

In this paper, we propose two selection schemes for DSVGD based on the Kernelized Stein Discrepancy (KSD) [36] and the Hilbert Inner Product (HIP) [37] for federated Bayesian learning. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We first propose a client selection scheme based on the KSD between the global posterior and the local tilted distribution. The client with a larger KSD will have a higher probability of being selected since it provides updates that maximize the decrease of the local free energy per iteration.

  • â€¢

    We also propose a scheme based on the HIP between the SVGD update function for the global and local likelihood. We derive the closed form of HIP using the properties of the Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS). The larger the HIP the higher the probability of a client being selected per iteration.

  • â€¢

    For both schemes, we derive the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy between any two consecutive iterations. It is revealed that both schemes improve the model convergence, where the KSD-based scheme has smaller communication overhead, but the HIP-based scheme has faster convergence.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the federated Bayesian learning framework and DSVGD. Section III proposes two client selection schemes and the corresponding convergence analysis. Section IV provides experimental results, followed by conclusions in Section V.

II System Model and Preliminaries

In this section, we first describe the considered system model and then introduce the technical preliminaries used in our paper. The key notations that are important for the system model and the technical preliminaries are summarized in Table I.

Specifically, Bayesian inference aims to obtain the posterior distribution, which is generally referred to as the target distribution, over the model parameters. Variational inference uses KL divergence to measure the similarity between two distributions and frames the Bayesian inference problem into a deterministic optimization that approximates the target distribution with a simpler distribution by minimizing their KL divergence. Therefore, global free energy refers to the KL divergence to be optimized in the variational inference, which is the KL divergence between the variational global posterior qâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘ğœƒq(\theta) and the optimal global posterior q~oâ€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹(Î¸)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘¡ğœƒ\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta), as shown in (2). Following the federated Bayesian learning framework in [23], we restrict qâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘ğœƒq(\theta) to the family of distributions having the following form:

  • â€¢

    Step 1: The server serially selects a client and sends the current variational global posterior q(iâˆ’1)superscriptğ‘ğ‘–1q^{(i-1)} to the selected client.

II-B Preliminaries

In this paper, we investigate the client selection problem in DSVGD, which is a novel federated Bayesian learning framework and applies SVGD to the federated Bayesian learning framework presented in Section II-A to solve the local free energy in (5). Next, we illustrate the preliminaries of KSD, SVGD, and DSVGD that are used in our algorithms.

II-B2 Stein Variational Gradient Descent

SVGD [24] is a non-parametric variational inference algorithm that aims to solve optimization problems of a similar form to (5). SVGD encodes the variational distribution qâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘ğœƒq(\theta) using a set of particles {Î¸n}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘›ğ‘›1ğ‘\{\theta_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} that are updated iteratively to match the (unnormalized) target distribution p~â€‹(Î¸)~ğ‘ğœƒ\tilde{p}(\theta) as

II-B3 Distributed Stein Variational Gradient Descent

DSVGD inherits the performance of SVGD in terms of bias, convergence speed, and per-iteration complexity by controlling the number of particles [23]. At each global iteration i=1,2,â€¦,Iğ‘–12â€¦ğ¼i=1,2,\ldots,I, DSVGD maintains a set of global particles {Î¸n(iâˆ’1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘›ğ‘–1ğ‘›1ğ‘\{\theta_{n}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at the server side, which represent the approximate posterior q(iâˆ’1)â€‹(Î¸)superscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğœƒq^{(i-1)}(\theta) of the current model parameters, and a set of local particles {Î¸n,k(iâˆ’1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘–1ğ‘›1ğ‘\{\theta_{n,k}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at the client side, which represent the approximate scaled local likelihood tk(iâˆ’1)â€‹(Î¸)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–1ğœƒt_{k}^{(i-1)}(\theta).   • â€¢

    Step 1: The server serially selects a client and sends the current global particles {Î¸n(iâˆ’1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘›ğ‘–1ğ‘›1ğ‘\{\theta_{n}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} to the selected client.

In this paper, we consider the selection problem for DSVGD which aims to select the client that contributes most to the decrease of the global free energy in each global iteration and thus improving convergence.

III Client Selection Schemes for Federated Bayesian Learning

In this section, we start by introducing a generic client selection framework for DSVGD. Then, we propose two schemes, namely KSD-based scheme and HIP-based scheme. Moreover, we analyze the convergence of DSVGD which reveals that both schemes improve the model convergence, where the KSD-based scheme has smaller communication overhead and the HIP-based scheme has faster convergence.

III-A Generic Client Selection Framework

We now introduce the generic client selection framework for federated Bayesian learning where the server estimates the selection distribution Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k}, for kâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,K}ğ‘˜12â€¦ğ¾k\in\{1,2,...,K\} which represents the probability of selecting client kğ‘˜k. At each global iteration iğ‘–i, a client kâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,K}ğ‘˜12â€¦ğ¾k\in\{1,2,...,K\} is selected based on the distribution Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} to update the global posterior. The step of this framework can be summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    Step 1 (Global Posterior Broadcast): The server broadcasts the current global posterior to all clients.

  • â€¢

    Step 2 (Importance Indicator Report): Each client kğ‘˜k computes an indicator and reports the result to the server. This step is going to be detailed later.

  • â€¢

    Step 3 (Selection Distribution Calculation): Based on the received reports, the server computes the selection distribution Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} of the clients.

  • â€¢

    Step 4 (Client Selection): Based on the selection distribution, the server selects a client, and then solicits updates from the selected client.

  • â€¢

    Step 5 (Global Posterior Update): The selected client minimizes local free energy in (5) to obtain the new global posterior.

  • â€¢

    Step 6 (Global Posterior Upload and Approximate Scaled Local Likelihood Update): The selected client uploads the global posterior obtained in the previous step to the server and updates the approximate scaled local likelihood using (7).

Note that the client selection requires the addition of three steps: the importance indicator report (Step 2), selection distribution calculation (Step 3) and client selection (Step 4) to the traditional federated learning process presented in Sec. II-A. Also, the global posterior needs to be broadcast to all clients at the beginning of each communication iteration, instead of being sent serially to each client.

III-B KSD-Based Scheme

Federated Bayesian learning converges as the variational global posterior qâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘ğœƒq(\theta) gradually approximates each local tilted distribution (see (5)), where the discrepancy between each local tilted distribution and the current variational global posterior is different. Here, we measure this discrepancy in terms of KSD, which can be easily estimated from the local tilted distribution and the global particles representing the variational global posterior. A larger KSD between the two distributions indicates that the variational global posterior has not sufficiently approximated the local tilted distribution, and therefore the client may have contributed more to the decrease of the global free energy. A naive idea is to use KSD as an indicator for judging the importance of the clientâ€™s data, assigning the client with larger KSD value a higher probability of selection. We next analyse the convergence of the global free energy by stating the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

If a client kğ‘˜k is selected, from local iteration lğ‘™l to l+1ğ‘™1l+1 during global iteration iğ‘–i, the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy can be expressed as

(Fâ€‹(q[l+1]â€‹(Î¸))âˆ’Fâ€‹(q[l]â€‹(Î¸)))/Î±â‰¤âˆ’Ïµâ€‹Sâ€‹(q[l],p~k)ğ¹superscriptğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘™1ğœƒğ¹superscriptğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘™ğœƒğ›¼italic-Ïµğ‘†superscriptğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘™subscript~ğ‘ğ‘˜\displaystyle\left(F(q^{[l+1]}(\theta))-F(q^{[l]}(\theta))\right)/\alpha\leq-\epsilon S(q^{[l]},\tilde{p}_{k})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\

where lmâ€‹aâ€‹x(i)=supÎ¸maxmâ‰ kâ¡|logâ¡(tm(iâˆ’1)â€‹(Î¸))â‹…pmâ€‹(Î¸)|superscriptsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptsupremumğœƒsubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘–1ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğœƒl_{max}^{(i)}=\sup_{\theta}\max_{m\neq k}\left|\log(t_{m}^{(i-1)}(\theta))\cdot p_{m}(\theta)\right|. Proof.

See Appendix A. âˆ

The first term on the right hand side of (1) corresponds to the upper bound of the decrease of the local free energy, expressed by the KSD between the local tilted distribution and the variational global posterior, while the second term of (1) corresponds to the upper bound of the impact of un-selected clients on the global free energy. Therefore, Lemma 1 shows that the decrease of the global free energy is influenced by both the selected clients and un-selected clients, where the selected client influences the decrease of global free energy through the decrease of the local free energy. It can be observed that the larger the clientâ€™s KSD is, the smaller the upper bound of the local free energy and the greater the contribution to the decrease of the local free energy. The idea is that the client with larger KSD will approximately reduce the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy while ignoring the effect of un-selected clients, and thus we use KSD to discriminate the importance of the clientâ€™s data, assigning a higher selection probability to the clients with larger KSD.

Definition 1.

The KSD-based selection distribution is defined as:

PKSD,k=Skâ€‹(q,p~k)âˆ‘m=1KSmâ€‹(q,p~m).subscriptğ‘ƒKSDğ‘˜subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘subscript~ğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptğ‘†ğ‘šğ‘subscript~ğ‘ğ‘š\displaystyle P_{{\rm KSD},k}=\frac{S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}S_{m}(q,\tilde{p}_{m})}. (17)

Here we use the KSD between the variational global posterior qâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘ğœƒq(\theta) and the local tilted distribution p~kâ€‹(Î¸)subscript~ğ‘ğ‘˜ğœƒ\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta) as an indicator for judging the importance of the clientsâ€™ data. Intuitively, the client with a larger KSD can be prioritized based on the selection distribution in (17). More specifically, the server can prioritise the selection of clients whose local tilted distribution is not sufficiently approximated by the variational global posterior. We present the KSD-based scheme in Algorithm 1 where the step 4 to the step 6 correspond to the extra steps added by the selection framework with respect to the DSVGD algorithm.

Comparison to the round robin and random selection schemes: With the impact of un-selected clients approximately ignored, the KSD-based scheme results in a tighter upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy compared to the round robin and random selection schemes, where the probability of each client being selected is set uniformly to 1K1ğ¾\frac{1}{K}. Specifically, defining Î”KSDsubscriptÎ”KSD\Delta_{\mathrm{KSD}} as the upper bound reduction from the KSD-based scheme compared to the round robin and random selection schemes, the bound of the KSD-based scheme is tighter if

which holds since

In such a condition, the difference between each local tilted distribution and the current variational global posterior is the same, indicating that the clientsâ€™ data is IID. In this case, Î”KSD=0subscriptÎ”KSD0\Delta_{\mathrm{KSD}}=0 and the KSD-based scheme no longer improves the performance of the model.

III-C HIP-based Scheme

The KSD-based scheme proposed in the previous subsection exploits the divergence between distributions as an indicator of the importance of the clientsâ€™ data. However, this scheme actually only achieves the minimization of the decrease of the local free energy per iteration, as it ignores the impact of un-selected clients on the global free energy for simplicity. In this subsection, we integrate the impact of both the selected and un-selected clients (which corresponds to the first and second term on the right hand side in (1)) on the global free energy through the HIP between two SVGD update functions.

We start by recalling the update function for particles in SVGD. According to the previous discussion in Section II-B, the update function is restricted to a zero-centered ball of a RKHS â„‹dsuperscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\mathcal{H}^{d} and is optimized to maximize the negative gradient of the KL divergence, which can be written in the form of the KSD as shown in (II-B2), and in turn can be further rewritten in the form of the HIP as âŸ¨Ï•,Ï•âˆ—âŸ©â„‹dsubscriptitalic-Ï•superscriptitalic-Ï•superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\langle\phi,\phi^{*}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} as shown in (9), where Ï•âˆ—â€‹(â‹…)=ğ”¼Î¸âˆ¼qâ€‹[âˆ‡logâ¡p~kâ€‹(Î¸)â€‹kâ€‹(Î¸,â‹…)+âˆ‡kâ€‹(Î¸,â‹…)]superscriptitalic-Ï•â‹…subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœƒğ‘delimited-[]âˆ‡subscript~ğ‘ğ‘˜ğœƒkğœƒâ‹…âˆ‡kğœƒâ‹…\phi^{*}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)] is referred to as the target update function for normalized distribution pkâ€‹(Î¸)âˆp~kâ€‹(Î¸)proportional-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğœƒsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘˜ğœƒp_{k}(\theta)\propto\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta). When the update function Ï•â€‹(Î¸)italic-Ï•ğœƒ\phi(\theta) is equal in size and direction to the target update function Ï•âˆ—â€‹(Î¸)superscriptitalic-Ï•ğœƒ\phi^{*}(\theta), the HIP can achieve a maximum value, when the norm of the ball is taken to be â€–Ï•âˆ—â€–â„‹d2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptitalic-Ï•superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘2\|\phi^{*}\|_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}^{2}. Similarly, when we choose a different update function, the difference in both the size and direction between it and the target update function in Hilbert space will cause the HIP to change, which in turn affects the speed at which the particles are updated towards the target distribution. Therefore, we can use the HIP between the update function Ï•â€‹(Î¸)italic-Ï•ğœƒ\phi(\theta) and the target update function Ï•â€‹(Î¸âˆ—)italic-Ï•superscriptğœƒ\phi(\theta^{*}) to measure the contribution of the particles update. A larger HIP indicates that the update function can make the variational distribution approach the target distribution at a faster speed, which makes a greater contribution to the particles update. This is formalized in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Given âŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•mâŸ©â„‹dsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} representing the HIP between the update functions for the likelihoods of client kğ‘˜k and client mğ‘šm, the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy per iteration can be written as

Here in Lemma 2, and in contrast with Lemma 1, only the first term in the upper bound is related to the selected client, and thus, the second term and the third term can be ignored. The first term is written in the from of the HIP, which is the sum of HIP between the update functions of the selected client kğ‘˜k and all clients including both the selected and un-selected clients. Specifically, the HIP term can be divided into âŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•kâŸ©â„‹dsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{k}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} and âˆ‘mâ‰ kâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•mâŸ©â„‹dsubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\sum_{m\neq k}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}. The term âŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•kâŸ©â„‹dsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{k}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} can be rewritten in the form of KSD as Sâ€‹(q,pk)ğ‘†ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜S(q,p_{k}), which represents the discrepancy between the local likelihood pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} of the selected client kğ‘˜k and the variational global posterior qğ‘q represented by the global particles. In addition, the impact of an un-selected client mğ‘šm is expressed as âŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•mâŸ©â„‹dsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}, which is the contribution of the SVGD update functions of the selected client kğ‘˜k to the update of particles towards the local likelihood pmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{m} of un-selected client mğ‘šm. Therefore, the term âˆ‘mâ‰ kâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•mâŸ©â„‹dsubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\sum_{m\neq k}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} manifest the impact of all un-selected clients by aggregating the contributions of the selected client kğ‘˜k that causes particles to update in different directions. Lemma 2 reveals that the larger the HIP term the smaller the upper bound on the decrease of the global free energy per iteration, indicating that the selected client can make a greater contribution to the decrease of the global free energy. We now state a lemma that will prove useful to further simplify the upper bound in lemma 2.

Lemma 3 transforms the sum of HIP into the HIP between the update function for the likelihood of client kğ‘˜k and the update function of the global averaged likelihood pâ€²=(âˆm=1Kpm)1Ksuperscriptğ‘â€²superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘š1ğ¾p^{\prime}=\left(\prod_{m=1}^{K}p_{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{K}}. According to the previous discussion, since pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime} is a geometric average of the local likelihoods across Kğ¾K clients, pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime} contains the likelihood information of all clients. Therefore, we define the global averaged likelihood as the target distribution, the sum of HIP in (2) represents the contribution of client kğ‘˜k to the update of the particles towards the global averaged likelihood, which contains information about all clients.

Therefore, we consider the HIP term âŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹dsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} as a measure of the importance of the clientsâ€™ data and assign higher selection probabilities to the clients with larger HIP.

Definition 2.

The HIP-based selection distribution is defined as:

PHIP,k=âŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹dâˆ‘m=1KâŸ¨Ï•m,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹d.subscriptğ‘ƒHIPğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šsuperscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\displaystyle P_{{\rm HIP},k}=\frac{\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{m},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}}. (24)

Here we use the HIP between the update function for local likelihood and the update function for the global averaged likelihood pâ€²=(âˆm=1Kpm)1Ksuperscriptğ‘â€²superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘š1ğ¾p^{\prime}=\left(\prod_{m=1}^{K}p_{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{K}} as an indicator for judging the importance of a clientâ€™s data. Intuitively, using (24), the server can prioritize the client who updates particles towards the global averaged likelihood at a faster speed, maximizing the decrease of the global free energy per iteration. Finally, we present the HIP-based scheme in Algorithm 2 where the step 4 to the step 6 corresponds the extra steps with respect to DSVGD and are added for selecting.

Comparison to the round robin and random selection schemes: The HIP-based scheme results in a tighter upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy compared to the round robin and random selection schemes. Specifically, we define Î”HIPsubscriptÎ”HIP\Delta_{\mathrm{HIP}} as the upper bound reduction from the HIP-based scheme compared to the round robin and random selection schemes, the bound of the HIP-based scheme is tighter if

Î”HIP=Ïµâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹dâ€‹PHIP,kâˆ’ÏµKâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹dâ‰¥0,subscriptÎ”HIPitalic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ƒHIPğ‘˜italic-Ïµğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘0\displaystyle\Delta_{\mathrm{HIP}}=\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}P_{\mathrm{HIP},k}-\frac{\epsilon}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}\geq 0, (25)

which holds since

Ïµâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹ditalic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\displaystyle\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} PHIP,ksubscriptğ‘ƒHIPğ‘˜\displaystyle P_{\mathrm{HIP},k}
=\displaystyle= Ïµâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹d2âˆ‘m=1KâŸ¨Ï•m,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹ditalic-Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘2superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šsuperscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\displaystyle\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}^{2}}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{m},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}}
â‰¥\displaystyle\geq ÏµKâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KâŸ¨Ï•k,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹d,(Jensenâ€‹Inequality)italic-Ïµğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘˜superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘JensenInequality\displaystyle\frac{\epsilon}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}},\quad\mathrm{(Jensen\leavevmode\nobreak\ Inequality)}

where the equality holds under the condition âŸ¨Ï•1,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹d=âŸ¨Ï•2,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹d=â€¦=âŸ¨Ï•K,Ï•â€²âŸ©â„‹dsubscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•1superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•2superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘â€¦subscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ¾superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²superscriptâ„‹ğ‘‘\left\langle\phi_{1},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}=\left\langle\phi_{2},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}=...=\left\langle\phi_{K},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}. In such a condition, the HIP between the local update function of each client and the global update function is the same, indicating that the clientsâ€™ data is IID. In this case, Î”HIP=0subscriptÎ”HIP0\Delta_{\mathrm{HIP}}=0 and the HIP-based scheme no longer improves the performance of the model.

IV Experimental Results

In this section, we conduct experiments to validate the theoretical analysis and test the performance of the proposed schemes.

IV-A Experiment Settings

As in [23] and [24], for all our experiments with SVGD and DSVGD, we use the Radial Basis Function (RBF) kernel kâ€‹(x,x0)=eâ€‹xâ€‹pâ€‹(âˆ’â€–xâˆ’x0â€–22/h)kğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥022â„\mathrm{k}(x,x_{0})=exp(-\|x-x_{0}\|_{2}^{2}/h) and take the bandwidth to be h=med2/logâ¡nâ„superscriptmed2ğ‘›h=\mathrm{med}^{2}/\log n where medmed\mathrm{med} is the median of the pairwise distance between the particles in the current iterate, so that the bandwidth hâ„h changes according to the set of particles adaptively across the iterations. As for the KSD estimator, we use the Gaussian kernel Kâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)Kâ‹…â‹…\mathrm{K}(\cdot,\cdot) where the bandwidth is set to 0.55. We use AdaGrad for step size and initialize the particles using the prior distribution unless otherwise specified. Finally, we fix the temperature parameter Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 in (1) throughout the iterations.

For exposition, we consider the learning task of training classifiers. Two prevalent learning models of Bayesian logistic regression (BLR) [39] and Bayesian Neural Networks (BNN) [40] are employed for implementation. First, We consider BLR model for binary classification using the same setting as in [39]. The model parameters is define as Î¸=[ğ°,logâ¡(Î¾)]ğœƒğ°ğœ‰\theta=[\mathbf{w},\log(\xi)] where parameter Î¾ğœ‰\xi is a precision and the regression weights ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} is assigned with a Gaussian prior p0â€‹(ğ°|Î¾)=ğ’©â€‹(ğ°|ğŸ,Î¾âˆ’1â€‹ğˆd)subscriptğ‘0conditionalğ°ğœ‰ğ’©conditionalğ°0superscriptğœ‰1subscriptğˆğ‘‘p_{0}(\mathbf{w}|\xi)=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{w}|\mathbf{0},\xi^{-1}\mathbf{I}_{d}) and p0â€‹(Î¾)=Gammaâ€‹(Î¾|1,0.01)subscriptğ‘0ğœ‰Gammaconditionalğœ‰10.01p_{0}(\xi)=\mathrm{Gamma}(\xi|1,0.01). Similarly, we consider multi-label classification with BNN model using the same setting as in [23]. The model parameters Î¸=[ğ–,logâ¡(Î³)]ğœƒğ–ğ›¾\theta=[\mathbf{W},\log(\gamma)] include a precision parameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma along with the weights of neural network ğ–ğ–\mathbf{W} assigned with a Gaussian prior p0â€‹(ğ–|Î»)=ğ’©â€‹(ğ–|ğŸ,Î»âˆ’1â€‹ğˆd)subscriptğ‘0conditionalğ–ğœ†ğ’©conditionalğ–0superscriptğœ†1subscriptğˆğ‘‘p_{0}(\mathbf{W}|\lambda)=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{W}|\mathbf{0},\lambda^{-1}\mathbf{I}_{d}) with a fixed precision Î»=eğœ†ğ‘’\lambda=e. The data of client kğ‘˜k is given as Dk={xi,yi}i=1Ksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ¾D_{k}=\{x_{i},y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K} and ynsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›y_{n} is obtained as yn=fâ€‹(xn;ğ–)+nsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ–ğ‘›y_{n}=f(x_{n};\mathbf{W})+n where the neural network output fâ€‹(â‹…;ğ–)ğ‘“â‹…ğ–f(\cdot;\mathbf{W}) is corrupted by additive noise variables nğ‘›n, where nâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î³âˆ’1)similar-toğ‘›ğ’©0superscriptğ›¾1n\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\gamma^{-1}). The number of hidden layers containing 100 hidden units is set to one and RELU is set as the activation function. The local likelihood at each client kğ‘˜k is given as pk=âˆxi,yiâˆˆDkpâ€‹(yi|xi,ğ–,Î³)subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptproductsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ–ğ›¾p_{k}=\prod_{x_{i},y_{i}\in D_{k}}p(y_{i}|x_{i},\mathbf{W},\gamma).

To better simulate the data distribution, we consider the non-IID data partitioning way as follows. For the BLR model, we choose the Covertype dataset, which contains two types of labels yâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}ğ‘¦11y\in\{-1,1\}. We define the number of clients as 30 and 120, where the ratio of the two categories in each clientâ€™s data is 1:9. For the BNN model, we choose nine typical classes from digit â€œ0â€ to â€œ8â€ in the well-known dataset MNIST for classification and define the number of clients as 27 and 120, where each client owns only three types of dataset, making the data distribution over clients a pathological non-IID manner. Moreover, since a pathological non-IID distribution of clients data, we set the number of local iterations to 10 to ensure that the model converges.

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed selection schemes, we implement two baseline schemes in the following experiments, the round robin selection scheme and the random selection scheme. Specifically, the round robin selection scheme is used by the authors of [23] in DSVGD, which selects each client in a certain order, and the random selection scheme is the more common selection scheme in federated learning, where the server randomly selects a client at each iteration. In addition, since the communication load caused by HIP-based selection scheme is similar to that of the parallel DSVGD algorithm, we also conduct experiment to compare the model performance between the two schemes.

IV-B KSD-Based Selection Scheme

Fig. 2(a) and Fig. 2(b) depicts the learning performance of the KSD-based scheme compared with the two baseline schemes using the BLR model. From the figure, we can observe that the KSD-based scheme achieves the same model convergence speed as the round robin scheme at the early stage of model training, and both schemes converge faster than the random selection scheme. In the later stage of model training, the KSD-based scheme outperforms the other two schemes, where the random scheme has lower model accuracy and worse model convergence, and the model accuracy curve of the round robin scheme vibrates periodically and substantially making the model have no tendency to converge. Fig. 2(c) and Fig. 2(d) illustrates the performance comparison among the three schemes using the BNN model. It can be observed that the model performance of the random selection scheme is the worst, and its model accuracy and convergence are inferior to the other two schemes, while the model performance of the KSD-based scheme is better than that of the round robin scheme. Specifically, with the KSD-based scheme, the convergence curve is more stable than that of the round robin scheme throughout the model training process. These two experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the KSD-based scheme, which achieves the maximization of the decrease of the local free energy.

IV-C HIP-Based Scheme

From Fig. 3, we observe the better performance of HIP-based scheme compared to that of two baseline schemes using the BLR model and BNN model. Specifically, with HIP-based scheme, the model accuracy curve is always stable than that of two baseline schemes and the model accuracy is almost always higher than that of two baseline schemes, which especially significant in late iterations, demonstrating that the HIP-based scheme, which aims at minimizing the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy, significantly improves the model performance in an environment with a pathological non-IID client data distribution, although the scheme causes more communication resources per iteration.

IV-D Comparison of the Two Proposed Schemes

We compare the model performance of the two proposed schemes in the BLR model and the BNN model. From Fig. 4, we observed that the performance of the HIP-based scheme is better, specifically, the convergence curve of the HIP-based scheme is more stable, while the convergence speed of the HIP-based scheme is slightly faster in the BNN model. This is consistent with the previous theoretical analysis that the KSD-based scheme considered only maximizing the decrease of the local free energy, while the HIP-based scheme maximizes the decrease of the global free energy and thus should exhibit better model performance.

IV-E Comparison with the Parallel DSVGD Algorithm

Fig. 5 depicts the performance of the HIP-based scheme compared with the parallel DSVGD algorithm using the BNN model. From this figure, we can observe that the convergence curve of the parallel DSVGD algorithm is more stable than that of the the HIP-based scheme, which is because the parallel DSVGD algorithm can use the likelihood information of all clients when updating the global particles, so that the global posterior does not favor a certain local likelihood. However, as the training proceeds, the model accuracy of the HIP-based scheme is asymptotically higher than that of the parallel DSVGD algorithm. The reason is that in the parallel DSVGD algorithm, there is an error in the KDE of the local particles uploaded at the client side, which does not accurately represent the information of the approximate scaled local likelihood, thus causing the loss of client data information in this step and degrading the accuracy of the model.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed two client selection schemes for federated Bayesian learning, namely the KSD-based scheme and the HIP-based scheme. Through convergence analysis, we found that the KSD-based scheme maximizes the decrease of the local free energy per iteration and the HIP-based scheme improves the model convergence by maximizing the decrease of the global free energy per iteration. Comprehensive experiments using real datasets confirmed the performance gain of the proposed schemes compared with the baseline schemes.
